The '''2023 United Nations Climate Change Conference''' or '''Conference of the Parties of the [[UNFCCC]]''', more commonly known as '''[[United Nations Climate Change conference|COP28]]''', was the 28th [[United Nations Climate Change conference]], held from 30 November to 13 December at [[Expo City Dubai|Expo City]], [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. The COP conference has been held annually (except 2020 due to the [[COVID-19]] pandemic)<ref>{{Cite web |title=Event: Glasgow Climate Change Conference (UNFCCC COP 26) {{!}} SDG Knowledge Hub {{!}} IISD |url=https://sdg.iisd.org/events/2020-un-climate-change-conference-unfccc-cop-26/ |access-date=2023-02-22 |language=en-US |archive-date=2021-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211017192030/https://sdg.iisd.org/events/2020-un-climate-change-conference-unfccc-cop-26/ |url-status=live }}</ref> since the [[Earth Summit|first UN climate agreement in 1992]]. The event is intended for governments to agree on policies to [[Climate change mitigation|limit global temperature rises]] and [[Climate change adaptation|adapt to impacts]] associated with [[climate change]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Stallard |first=Esme |title=COP27: What is the Egypt climate conference and why is it important? |date=25 October 2022 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-63316362 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |access-date=27 October 2022 |archive-date=2023-02-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230214173620/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-63316362 |url-status=live }}</ref>

The conference was originally scheduled to end on 12 December, but had to be extended following [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] objections on the final agreement.<ref>{{Cite news |last=El Dahan |first=Maha |date=13 December 2023 |title=COP28 agreeable to Saudis as it lets nations chart own course - source |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/cop28-agreeable-saudis-it-lets-nations-chart-own-course-source-2023-12-13/ |access-date=2023-12-20 |archive-date=2023-12-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231213141621/https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/cop28-agreeable-saudis-it-lets-nations-chart-own-course-source-2023-12-13/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On 13 December, the conference president, [[Sultan Al Jaber]] announced that a final compromise agreement between the countries involved had been reached. The deal commits all signatory countries to move away from carbon energy sources "in a just, orderly and equitable manner" to mitigate the worst effects of climate change, and reach [[Net zero emissions|net zero]] by 2050.<ref name=":032">{{Cite news |last1=Morton |first1=Adam |last2=Harvey |first2=Fiona |last3=Greenfield |first3=Patrick |date=13 December 2023 |title=Cop28 landmark deal ==Background==

=== Host city ===
The United Nations Climate Change Conference is an annual meeting of all countries that have signed the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|1994 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]]. It is held annually, with the host countries rotating among its members.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hutton |first=H. |date=2022-10-13 |title=What is COP? |url=https://www.cisl.cam.ac.uk/cop-climate-change-conference |access-date=2024-04-13 |website=Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership (CISL) |language=en |archive-date=2024-04-25  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240425192937/https://www.cisl.cam.ac.uk/cop-climate-change-conference |url-status=live }}</ref> In early 2021, the [[United Arab Emirates]] offered to host the 2023 event.<ref name=":0" /> Dubai was chosen as the host city in November of the same year. It was the third time it was hosted by a member of [[OPEC]] after [[Qatar]] in 2012 and [[Indonesia]] in 2007.<ref>{{Cite news |date=November 12, 2021 |title=Dubai ruler says UAE to host COP28 climate conference in 2023 |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/cop/dubai-ruler-says-uae-host-cop28-climate-conference-2023-2021-11-11/ |access-date=2024-04-13 |work=Reuters |archive-date=2023-02-25  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230225115739/https://www.reuters.com/business/cop/dubai-ruler-says-uae-host-cop28-climate-conference-2023-2021-11-11/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

The United Arab Emirates is one of the most climate-vulnerable countries in the world, due to its very hot and humid climate. Its average air temperature has risen by {{cvt|1.27|C}} between 1990 and 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal |url=https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/ |access-date=2023-11-24 |website=climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org |language=en |archive-date=2021-09-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210908011654/https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The [[Red Sea]] and [[Persian Gulf]] have exceeded safe [[wet-bulb temperature]] thresholds several times.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Carter |first1=M. storm]]s, [[sea level rise]] and [[drought]].<ref>{{cite web |title=United Arab Emirates |first=Stanley}}</ref> It was also the first country in the region to sign the [[Paris Agreement]] on 21 September 2016.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Wright |first=Caroline |date=17 February 2022 |title=How ==== Reception ====
The choice of the UAE as host country was criticized by climate scientists and human rights advocates, as the country is both a leading oil producer and an authoritarian state without [[freedom of speech]]. The Emirati organisers warned speakers not to criticise Islam or the Emirati government, corporations or individuals.<ref name=":7" /> [[Human Rights Watch]] urged governments to use the opportunity to push the UAE to ease the "grip on civic space and uphold rights" and end the persecution of human rights activists like [[Ahmed Mansoor]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Stork |first=Joe |date=2023-06-13 |title=Governments at Bonn Climate Talks Should Press UAE on Rights |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2023/06/13/governments-bonn-climate-talks-should-press-uae-rights |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200102225119/https://www.hrw.org/news/2023/06/13/governments-bonn-climate-talks-should-press-uae-rights |archive-date=2020-01-02 |access-date=2023-06-19 |work=Human Right Watch |language=en}}</ref> On 1 August 2023, the UAE allowed environmental activists to "assemble peacefully" at the summit and vowed to provide them a space to "make their voices heard", despite laws that prohibit unauthorised protests.<ref>{{cite web |title=UAE vows to allow 'peaceful' assembly of climate activists at COP28 |website=France24 |date=2023-08-01 |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20230801-uae-vows-to-allow-peaceful-assembly-of-climate-activists-at-cop28-1 |access-date=2023-08-02 |archive-date=2023-08-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230801165354/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20230801-uae-vows-to-allow-peaceful-assembly-of-climate-activists-at-cop28-1 |url-status=live }}</ref>

The UAE's appointment of [[Sultan Al Jaber]] president of COP28 caused further controversy, as he is also the CEO of [[Abu Dhabi National Oil Company]] (ADNOC).<ref name=":5">{{Cite news |last=Bikales |first=James |date=2023-05-28 |title=US and EU lawmakers call for UAE to remove Jaber from UN climate role |url=https://www.ft.com/content/34fb5016-d9f4-4d4d-9bb4-174bfcadbe77 |url-status=live === Preparations ===
In the months leading up to the summit, joint preparations were held by the United States, China, and the European Union. The climate envoys of the U.S. ([[John Kerry]]), China ([[Xie Zhenhua (politician)|Xie Zhenhua]]) and the E.U. ([[Frans Timmermans]]) met regularly to discuss priorities and planning.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Liwei |first1=Wang |last2=Yining |first2=Xia |last3=Xintong |first3=Wang |title=China Agrees to 'Bridge Building' With U.S., EU at Upcoming Climate Summit |url=https://www.globalneighbours.org/china-agrees-to-bridge-building-with-u-s-eu-at-upcoming-climate-summit/ |website=Global neighbors |date=27 September 2023 |access-date=29 September 2023 |archive-date=2023-10-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231002113600/https://www.globalneighbours.org/china-agrees-to-bridge-building-with-u-s-eu-at-upcoming-climate-summit/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On November 15, the U.S. and China announced an agreement to triple global renewable energy use by 2030. === Draft and final agreements ===
On December 11, the day before the summit was scheduled to end, an initial draft of the final agreement was released. It was widely rejected by most Western countries because it avoided calling for a fossil fuel phaseout;<ref name=":1">{{Cite news |last=Volcovici |first=Valerie |last2=Abnett |first2=Kate |last3=Spring |first3=Jake |date=December 12, 2023 |title=COP28 forced into overtime as fossil fuel phase-out divides countries |url=https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/climate-energy/cop28-presidency-wants-historic-mention-fossil-fuels-text-up-nations-2023-12-12/ |access-date=2024-04-14 |work=Reuters |archive-date=2024-03-12  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240312160940/https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/climate-energy/cop28-presidency-wants-historic-mention-fossil-fuels-text-up-nations-2023-12-12/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The [[Alliance of Small Island States]] described the draft as a "death certificate" for small island nations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/12/cop-28-australia-us-and-uk-say-they-wont-sign-agreement-that-would-be-death-certificate-for-small-islands|title=Cop28: Australia, US and UK say they won't sign agreement that would be 'death certificate' for small islands|first=Adam|last=Morton|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=12 December 2023|access-date=12 December 2023|archive-date=2023-12-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231212011105/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/12/cop-28-australia-us-and-uk-say-they-wont-sign-agreement-that-would-be-death-certificate-for-small-islands|url-status=live}}</ref> Several African countries countered that wealthy countries had an obligation to take the lead on phasing out fossil fuels before expecting poorer countries to do so. [[OPEC]], a cartel of oil-producing countries, also urged participants to reject any mention of phasing out fossil fuels.<ref name=":1" /> After two days of intense negotiations, a compromise was reached under which the final text called for countries to "end their dependence" on fossil fuels "in a just, orderly and equitable manner", while stopping short of calling for a full phase-out. The agreement also called for a tripling of global renewable energy capacity by 2030,<ref name=":032" /><ref name=":122">{{Cite news |last=Plumer |first=Brad |date=13 December 2023 |title=In a First, Nations at Climate Summit Agree to Move Away From Fossil Fuels |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/13/climate/cop28-climate-agreement.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231213080049/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/13/climate/cop28-climate-agreement.html/ |archive-date=2023-12-13 |access-date=13 December 2023 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> the development of numerous "zero- and low-emission technologies",<ref name=":032" /> further efforts "towards the phase-down of unabated coal power"<ref name=":032" /> and a cut in [[methane emissions]].<ref name=":122" /> China and India did not sign the pledge to triple their output of renewable energy, and committed to coal power instead.<ref name="Slav 2023 z572" /><ref name="Lin 2023 n100" />

For the first time in the history of COP summits, the global pact explicitly mentioned the necessity to shift away from all kinds of fossil fuels;<ref name=":032"/><ref name=":122"/> however, the deal [[Air pollution|Air pollution's]] increase of [[Respiratory disease|respiratory conditions]] and increases the risk of [[cancer]] and [[Cardiovascular disease|heart disease]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tobias |first=Janet |last2=Wiskel |first2=Tess |date=2023-12-13 |title=At COP 28, global consensus on how climate change affects health |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/at-cop-28-global-consensus-on-how-climate-change-affects-health |access-date=2024-04-13 |website=PBS NewsHour |language=en-us |archive-date=2024-04-17  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240417213640/https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/at-cop-28-global-consensus-on-how-climate-change-affects-health |url-status=live }}</ref> In a letter addressed to Sultan Al Jaber, "organisations representing more than 46 million health professionals" said a complete phase-out of fossil fuels was the only decisive way to deliver health for all.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-02 |title=Ahead of COP28, over 46 million health professionals call for pledge to phase out fossil fuels |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/cities/pune/cop28-health-professionals-call-pledge-phase-out-fossil-fuels-9010096/ |access-date=2023-11-14 |website=The Indian Express |language=en |archive-date=2023-11-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231114151526/https://indianexpress.com/article/cities/pune/cop28-health-professionals-call-pledge-phase-out-fossil-fuels-9010096/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== Food systems ===
COP28 is the first COP where food systems were discussed. During the event, the UAE Declaration on Sustainable Agriculture, Resilient Food Systems, and Climate Action was adopted by 159 countries.<ref name=":11"/> Two-thirds of the estimated 250,000 meals served at the event were plant-based. The UN's [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] issued a roadmap report at the event outlining how to reduce agricultural emissions from methane. Food journalist [[Avery Yale Kamila]] said the roadmap "would require Americans to cut food waste and to move to flexitarian diets with far fewer animal products."<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-24 |title=Plant-based food gets seat at U.N. climate summit’s table |url=https://www.pressherald.com/2023/12/24/plant-based-food-gets-seat-at-u-n-climate-summits-table/ |access-date=2024-02-08 |website=Portland Press Herald |archive-date=2024-02-08  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240208154346/https://www.pressherald.com/2023/12/24/plant-based-food-gets-seat-at-u-n-climate-summits-table/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Controversies ==
=== Greenwashing accusations ===
Prior to the conference, the UAE hired PR and lobbying agencies, including [[Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld]], Gulstan Advisory and [[FleishmanHillard]], to improve its poor reputation on climate change.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Michaelson |first1=Ruth |last2=Greenfield |first2=Patrick |date=2022-11-16 |title=UAE using role as Cop28 host to lobby on its climate reputation |language=en |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/nov/16/uae-cop28-host-lobby-climate-reputation-cop27 |access-date=2023-05-30 |archive-date=2020-01-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200102225119/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/nov/16/uae-cop28-host-lobby-climate-reputation-cop27 |url-status=live }}</ref> Allegations surfaced regarding attempts to manipulate public perception, including that Al Jaber's team had edited Wikipedia to portray him more favorably. [[Abu Dhabi National Oil Company|ADNOC]] and [[Masdar]] also paid Wikipedia editors to lobby for changes to their respective pages, although the users followed Wikipedia's [[Conflict-of-interest editing on Wikipedia|conflict-of-interest rules]].<ref name=":6">{{Cite news |last=Stockton |first=Ben |date=2023-05-30 |title=Cop28 president's team accused of Wikipedia 'greenwashing' |language=en |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/may/30/cop28-president-team-accused-of-wikipedia-greenwashing-sultan-al-jaber |access-date=2023-05-31 |archive-date=2023-05-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230530052124/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/may/30/cop28-president-team-accused-of-wikipedia-greenwashing-sultan-al-jaber |url-status=live }}</ref> Reports also emerged of the proliferation of fake social media accounts on [[Twitter]] and [[Medium (website)|Medium]], aimed at promoting COP28 and defending the UAE's presidency.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-06-08 |title=Army of fake social media accounts defend UAE presidency of climate summit |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jun/08/army-of-fake-social-media-accounts-defend-uae-presidency-of-climate-summit |access-date=2023-06-08 |archive-date=2023-06-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230608140153/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jun/08/army-of-fake-social-media-accounts-defend-uae-presidency-of-climate-summit |url-status=live }}</ref>

Campaigning journalist [[Amy Westervelt]] argued that a newly added requirement to for [[Lobbying|industry lobbyists]] to identify themselves at COP28 was inadequate to control their influence.<ref name="westervelt-2023">{{cite news |last=Westervelt |first=Amy |title=So what if fossil fuel lobbyists have to declare themselves at COP28? === Treatment of migrant workers ===
The UAE has been adapting its conference facility, the prior site for [[Expo 2020]], to host the COP28 climate conference. FairSquare, a UK-based human rights group, released a report based on testimonies and photographs, stating that the migrant workers were being exposed to dangerously hot weather and humidity to prepare for the climate summit. According to the rights group, in September 2023, a dozen migrant workers from Asia and Africa were working outdoors in temperatures hitting {{cvt|42|C}} despite a midday ban. COP28 denied the allegations and claimed that no evidence of the midday ban's breach was found. A worksite supervisor said most of the work is done at night, but some has to be done whenever possible. A COP28 spokesperson said contractors were required to have worker heat safety plans and weather stations that monitor the [[Thermal work limit|Thermal Work Limit]], as well as taking into account heat and humidity metrics including wet and dry bulb temperature and wind speed.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lakhani |first=Nina |title=Migrant workers toil in perilous heat to prepare for Cop28 climate talks in UAE |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/20/cop28-migrant-workers-uae-heat-climate-crisis |access-date=31 October 2023 |work=The Guardian |date=20 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231020071429/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/20/cop28-migrant-workers-uae-heat-climate-crisis |archive-date=20 October 2023}}</ref>

=== Digital surveillance ===
Ahead of COP28, [[Amnesty International]] raised concerns that the UAE might continue to use digital surveillance to spy on human rights defenders and civil society members in the UAE, including the COP28 participants. According to Amnesty International's Disrupting Surveillance Team, the UAE had a record of using digital surveillance to "crush dissents and stifle freedom of expression". Amnesty's view of the UAE's promise to offer a "platform for activists' voices" would be unachievable without respect for the human rights of privacy and the right of peaceful assembly. Amnesty opposed the "unlawful electronic surveillance of conference participants [and of] Emirati nationals and residents". It said that the COP28 attendees should be allowed to download "privacy-respecting international communications applications" in the UAE that would ensure safe and encrypted means of communication.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-11-15 |title=UAE: Concerns around authorities' use of digital surveillance during COP28 |language=en |work=Amnesty International |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2023/11/uae-concerns-around-authorities-use-of-digital-surveillance-during-cop28/ |access-date=2023-11-23 |archive-date=2023-11-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231123124208/https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2023/11/uae-concerns-around-authorities-use-of-digital-surveillance-during-cop28/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="euronews 2023 e345">{{cite web | title=COP28: Activists fear surveillance and arrests at Dubai climate summit | website=Euronews | date=2023-11-24 | url=https://www.euronews.com/green/2023/11/24/repressive-state-activists-raise-concerns-about-surveillance-and-arrest-at-cop28 | access-date=2023-11-29 | archive-date=2023-11-29 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231129024819/https://www.euronews.com/green/2023/11/24/repressive-state-activists-raise-concerns-about-surveillance-and-arrest-at-cop28 | url-status=live }}</ref>

The head of the [[International Monetary Fund]], [[Kristalina Georgieva]], expressed satisfaction from the beginning of the conference because the [[Loss and damage (climate change)|loss and damage fund]] was created, but said that for further decarbonisation [[carbon pricing]] should be advanced and [[fossil fuel subsidies]] eliminated. Fossil fuel subsidies reached a record level of 7.1 trillion dollars in the year 2022, due to high fuel prices and inflation.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Al-Oraibi |first1=Mina |last2=Kamel |first2=Deena |date=4 December 2023 |title=Cop28 'successful from day one' with win on loss and damage fund, IMF chief says |url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/climate/cop28/2023/12/04/cop-28-successful-from-day-one-with-early-win-on-loss-and-damage-fund-imf-chief-says/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231204222450/https://www.thenationalnews.com/climate/cop28/2023/12/04/cop-28-successful-from-day-one-with-early-win-on-loss-and-damage-fund-imf-chief-says/ |archive-date=2023-12-04 |access-date=4 December 2023 |website=COP 28}}</ref> There are propositions for a creation of a global carbon market managed by the [[United Nations]] in the conference. Some steps are already done.<ref>{{cite web |title=Commission President advances global cooperation on carbon pricing in high-level event at COP28 |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/IP_23_6092 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231204222340/https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/IP_23_6092 |archive-date=2023-12-04 |access-date=4 December 2023 |website=European Commission |publisher=European Union}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=24 November 2023 |title=COP 28 holds key to global carbon market that could help improve offsets |url=https://www.energyvoice.com/markets/542024/cop-28-holds-key-to-global-carbon-market-that-could-help-improve-offsets/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231204222353/https://www.energyvoice.com/markets/542024/cop-28-holds-key-to-global-carbon-market-that-could-help-improve-offsets/ |archive-date=2023-12-04 |access-date=4 December 2023 |website=Energy Voice |publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Bedford |first1=Charles |date=30 November 2023 |title=At COP28 & beyond, fair carbon markets must be part of the climate finance solution (commentary) |url=https://news.mongabay.com/2023/11/at-cop28-beyond-fair-carbon-markets-must-be-part-of-the-climate-finance-solution-commentary/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231202090623/https://news.mongabay.com/2023/11/at-cop28-beyond-fair-carbon-markets-must-be-part-of-the-climate-finance-solution-commentary/ |archive-date=2023-12-02 |access-date=4 December 2023 |website=Mongabay}}</ref>

On 6 December 2023, [[Haitham al-Ghais]], the current OPEC Secretary-General, urged member nations to focus negotiations on reducing carbon emissions, rather than prohibiting the extraction and sale of fossil fuels.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Friedman |first=Lisa |date=8 December 2023 |title=OPEC Leader Tells Members to Block Any Climate Summit Deal to Curb Fossil Fuels |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/08/climate/opec-cop28-climate-oil.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231209020538/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/08/climate/opec-cop28-climate-oil.html |archive-date=2023-12-09 |access-date=8 December 2023 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> As a reaction, [[Greenpeace]] published a press release calling for Arab countries to phase out fossil fuels by 2050, ensuring a [[just transition]]. Greenpeace said that "The latest research from Christian Aid and the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Vienna shows that both the [[United Arab Emirates]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] face a GDP growth reduction of −72% by 2100 if the global temperature rise is allowed to reach 3°C."<ref>{{cite web |title=Arab countries must support UAE in bidding farewell to fossil fuels at COP28 |url=https://www.greenpeace.org/mena/en/arab-countries-cop28/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214071146/https://www.greenpeace.org/mena/en/arab-countries-cop28/ |archive-date=2023-12-14 |access-date=12 December 2023 |website=Greenpeace}}</ref> The study called ''Mercury Rising: the economic impact of climate change on the Arabian Peninsula'' predicts a 69% drop in GDP growth for countries at the Persian Gulf in average, with the highest impact on Saudi Arabia, [[Kuwait]], [[Qatar]] and the UAE if temperatures will reach this level. If temperature rise will be limited to 1.5 degrees, the reduction in economic growth will be limited to 8.2% by 2050 and 36% by 2100.<ref>{{cite web |date=9 December 2023 |title=UAE RISKS UP TO −72% GDP GROWTH HIT DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE: REPORT |url=https://carboncopy.info/uae-risks-up-to-72-gdp-growth-hit-due-to-climate-change-report/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214072202/https://carboncopy.info/uae-risks-up-to-72-gdp-growth-hit-due-to-climate-change-report/ |archive-date=2023-12-14 |access-date=12 December 2023 |website=Carbon copy}}</ref>
